test.title: Casio Notes Feature Demo
test.content:
Casio Notes Feature Demo
Welcome to the Casio Notes feature demonstration. This page highlights the custom styling and functionality implemented in this Quartz setup.
1. Metadata & Frontmatter
Notice the metadata displayed at the top of this page (below the title). It pulls from the YAML frontmatter:

Difficulty: Intermediate
Prerequisites: Basic Markdown
Status: In Progress

2. Typography & Math
The site uses Comfortaa for headings and body text, and IBM Plex Mono for code.
Here is some inline math: e^(i pi) + 1 = 0.
And a block equation:
integral_(-infinity)^infinity e^(-x^2) dif x = sqrt(pi)
3. Custom Callouts
We have customized callouts to match the Casio theme.


                  
                  Terminology 
                  
                

Casio Wave: A style inspired by retro-futurism and clean, functional aesthetics.




                  
                  Note 
                  
                

This is a standard note. It uses the secondary color for accents.




                  
                  Shannon's Theorem 
                  
                

Given a channel with bandwidth B and signal-to-noise ratio S/N, the channel capacity C is:
C = B log_2(1 + S/N)




                  
                  Proof 
                  
                

The proof is left as an exercise for the reader.




                  
                  Code Example 
                  
                

def hello_world():
    print("Hello, Casio!")


4. Footnotes & Popovers
We use footnotes that display as popovers on hover.
This is a statement with a footnote1.
And here is another one2.
5. Citations
Citations are linked to the bibliography.

Einstein’s famous paper [@einstein1905].
A classic textbook [@griffiths2005].
Information theory [@shannon1948].

6. Graph & Linking
This note is linked to linked-note.
Check the Graph View on the right to see the connection.
Also, check the Backlinks section below to see pages that link here.
7. Comments
Scroll down to the bottom to see the Giscus comment section (if configured).
